column1: #text=        Child Abuse Olya Polishchuk Mary Wyers, M.D.Children's Memorial Hospital  Abstract 1 year old male with trauma  Keywords lumbar injury, trauma, injury, child abuse, CT, MRI, plain film
column4: Publication Date: 2004-06-14                History 1 year old male with trauma    Findings CT: Translational injury at the L1/L2 level in the spine.

column1: #text=With respect to L1, L2 is displaced almost one vertebral body anteriorly by 12 mm, and left by 4 mm.
#text= MRI: Grade 3/4 anterolisthesis of L2 on L1 resulting in significant narrowing of the central spinal canal.
#text=A small amount of CSF is noted along the ventral and dorsal aspect of the conus medullaris, however there is no evidence of compression deformity of the conus medullaris.
#text=Evidence of prevertebral abnormality signal probably representing hemorrhage along the ventral aspect of the vertebral bodies from T11 through L1.
#text=Plain film: Healing fractures of radius and ulna.

#text=  Diagnosis  Child Abuse    Differential True Trauma    Discussion  Child abuse has many names such as nonaccidental trauma, battered child syndrome, shaken infant syndrome, and suspected child abuse and neglect (SCAN).
#text=It occurs in all socioeconomic groups and races.
#text=Radiographically, skeletal and brain injuries are seen most frequently in patients under 2 years of age.
#text=These injuries are much less common in patients who are 4 years or older.
#text=The hallmark of child abuse in the skeleton is multiple fractures in various stages of healing.
#text=However, a single fracture is more commonly seen.
#text=Single fracture is commonly present in long bones.
#text=Most commonly affected long bones are femur followed by tibia.
#text=Other clues to diagnosis are fractures that are unusual for that particular child's age or reported trauma.
#text=The "classic" fracture associated with child abuse is the corner metaphyseal fracture or "bucket-handle" fracture, resulting when metaphysis is pulled off.

column2:

column1: #text=Other injuries associated with child abuse include rib fractures and subdural hematomas in the head.
#text= The spine dislocation is an unusual injury in this case.
#text=However, any injury that does not match the trauma should raise the suspicion of child abuse    References  Williamson, S., PRIMARY PEDIATRIC RADIOLOGY, W.B.
#text=Lonergan, G., Baker, A.M., Morey, M.K., Boos, S.C., CHILD ABUSE: RADIOLOGIC-PATHOLOGIC CORRELATION, AFIP Archives, RadioGraphics 2003, 23: 811-845.
